translation: What power surpasses fate? Its will  Persists against the human skill
explanation: What is stronger than fate ? If we think of an expedient (to avert it), it will itself be with us before (the thought)
mk: இயற்கை நிலையை மாற்றி மற்றொரு செயற்கை நிலையை அமைத்திட முனைந்தாலும், இயற்கை நிலையே முதன்மையாக வந்து நிற்பதால் அதைவிட வலிமையானவையாக வேறு எவை இருக்கின்றன?
mv: ஊழை விட மிக்க வலிமையுள்ளவை வேறு எவை உள்ளன, ஊழை விலக்கும் பொருட்டு மற்றோரு வழியைஆராய்ந்தாலும் அங்கும் தானே முன் வந்து நிற்கும்.
sp: விதியை வெல்ல வேறொரு வழியை எண்ணி நாம் செயற்பட்டாலும், அந்த வழியிலேயோ வேறு ஒரு வழியிலேயோ அது நம்முன் வந்து நிற்கும்‌; ஆகவே விதியை விட வேறு எவை வலிமையானவை?
gptExplanation:
Kural 380 explores the concept of fate and its relentless power that surpasses any human effort. This verse asks a rhetorical question - "What is stronger than fate?" It then goes on to explain that even if we devise a strategy or a plan to avert or change our fate, fate itself will already be present there before we even begin to act upon our plan.

This verse illustrates the idea that fate or destiny, as believed in many cultures, is an inevitable force that cannot be easily altered by human actions. It implies that whatever is destined to happen will happen, regardless of the measures we take to prevent or change it.

In addition, this verse can also be interpreted as a philosophical commentary on the unpredictability of life. It teaches the wisdom of acceptance and humility in the face of life's uncertainties and the futility of trying to control or predict everything in our lives.

This Kural does not advocate fatalism or inaction, but rather it emphasizes the importance of understanding our limitations in the grand scheme of life and the universe. It also encourages us to focus on our actions and responsibilities, without being overly concerned or anxious about the outcomes which are beyond our control.
